metadata.title: Topological expansion in the cubic random matrix model
metadata.abstract: In this paper we return to the classical work by Br\'ezin, Itzykson, Parisi and Zuber, in which, among other things, the authors explicitly calculated the coefficients of the topological expansion in the cubic random matrix model in genus 0. Our main goal will be to rigorously prove the results of Br\'ezin, Itzykson, Parisi and Zuber and to obtain an explicit formula for the coefficients of the topological expansion in genus 1. We will also prove some formulae and asymptotic results for the coefficients of the topological expansion in higher genera.

grobid.contents:
TOPOLOGICAL EXPANSION IN THE CUBIC RANDOM MATRIX MODEL
21 Nov 2011

Pavel Bleher 
Alfredo Deaño 
TOPOLOGICAL EXPANSION IN THE CUBIC RANDOM MATRIX MODEL
21 Nov 2011
In this paper we study the topological expansion in the cubic random matrix model, and we evaluate explicitly the expansion coefficients for genus 0 and 1. For genus 0 our formula coincides with the one of Brézin, Itzykson, Parisi, and Zuber[6]. For the expansion coefficients of higher genus we obtain their asymptotic behavior as the number of vertices of the associated graphs tends to infinity. Our study is based on the Riemann-Hilbert problem, string equations, and the Toda equation.Date: November 22, 2011.

Introduction and statement of the main results

In this paper we return to the classical work [6] by Brézin, Itzykson, Parisi and Zuber, in which, among other things, the authors explicitly calculated the coefficients of the topological expansion in the cubic random matrix model in genus 0. Our main goal will be to rigorously prove the results of [6] and to obtain an explicit formula for the coefficients of the topological expansion in genus 1. We will also prove some formulae and asymptotic results for the coefficients of the topological expansion in higher genera.

We consider the random matrix model given by The partition function of eigenvalues,
Z N (u) = ∞ −∞ . . . ∞ −∞ 1≤j<k≤N (z j − z k ) 2 N j=1 e −N z 2 j 2 −uz 3 j dz 1 . . . dz N (1.4)
diverges as well on the real line. To regularize it, we will consider integration on a specially chosen contour Γ in the complex plane: To choose Γ, consider the three sectors on the complex plane, S 0 = z ∈ C : 5π 6 < arg z < 7π 6 , S 1 = z ∈ C : π 6 < arg z < π 4 , converges for any k = 0, 1, . . . and any u ≥ 0. Therefore, we will use contours consisting of two rays in the sectors S 0 , S 1 , and S 2 . More specifically, we may consider the three contours on the complex plane,
Z N (u) = Γ . . . Γ 1≤j<k≤N (z j − z k ) 2 N j=1 e −NS 2 = z ∈ C : − π 4 < arg z < − π 6 ,(1.Γ 0 = R π ∪ R π/5 , Γ 1 = R π ∪ R −π/5 , Γ 2 = R −π/5 ∪ R π/5 ,(1.9)

However, to get the topological expansion of the free energy, we will use Γ = Γ 0 or Γ = Γ 1 , but not Γ = Γ 2 . More generally, following Duits and Kuijlaars [13], it is convenient to introduce a linear combination of the contours Γ 0 , Γ 1 . To that end, let us fix some α ∈ C and consider Γ as a linear combination of Γ 0 , Γ 1 ,
Γ = αΓ 0 + (1 − α)Γ 1 ,

By the Cauchy theorem, we have some flexibility in the choice of the contours Γ 0 , Γ 1 within the sectors S 0 , S 1 , S 2 . It is easy to see, by differentiation of the integral with respect to u, that the partition function Z N (u; α) is analytic for u > 0, and it is infinitely differentiable for u ≥ 0. Observe, however, that Z N (u; α) is not analytic at u = 0. Indeed, the analytic continuation of Z N (u), u > 0, to u = re −3iθ , r > 0, can be obtained by the change of variable z j = w j e iθ : Z N (re −3iθ ; α) = Γ . . . (1.12)

By the Cauchy theorem, one can use the same contour Γ = Γ(α) for all θ. For θ = π 2 , the exponential term in the latter formula becomes (1. 13) hence Z N (u; α) is not analytic at u = 0. We define the free energy as F N (u; α) = 1 N 2 ln Z N (u; α) Z N (0; α) .

(1.14)

Observe that Z N (0; α) is independent of α. The aim of this paper is to investigate the large N asymptotic behavior of the free energy, and, in particular, the structure of the different terms that appear in this asymptotic expansion. We consider u in the interval 0 ≤ u < u c , where u c is the following critical value:
u c = 3 1/4 18 . (1.15)
We prove the following results:

Theorem 1.1. Suppose that α ∈ C is fixed. Then for any 0 ≤ u < u c , the free energy F N (u; α) admits an asymptotic expansion in inverse powers of N 2 : 16) which is uniform in the variable u on any interval [0, u c − ε], ε > 0 and which can be differentiated on [0, u c − ε] with respect to u any number of times, with a uniform estimate of the error term with respect to u ∈ [0, u c − ε]. The functions F (2g) (u) do not depend on α and they admit an analytic continuation to the disk |u| < u c in the complex plane, and if we expand them in powers of u,
F N (u; α) ∼ ∞ g=0 F (2g) (u) N 2g ,(1.F (2g) (u) = ∞ j=1 f (2g)

is a positive integer number that counts the number of 3-valent connected graphs with 2j vertices on a Riemann surface of genus g.

The existence of the 1 N 2 asymptotic expansion for the free energy is known in the physical literature since the classical work of Bessis, Itzykson, Zuber [7] (see also references therein to the earlier works). A rigorous proof of the 1 N 2 asymptotic expansion for the free energy for a general polynomial V (M ) of even degree is given in the paper of Ercolani and McLaughlin [15]. Our proof of Theorem 1.1 follows the work [15], with some modifications related to the fact that the cubic model is defined on the contour Γ in the complex plane and not on the real line.

It is worth noticing that the coefficients F (2g) (u) of asymptotic expansion (1.16) in powers of 1/N 2 do not depend on α for all 0 ≤ u < u c . The dependence on α arises, however, in the double scaling limit as u → u c . We will return to this question in a subsequent paper. (See also the paper [13] of Duits and Kuijlaars, where a similar double scaling limit is studied for the quartic random matrix model.)

F (4) = 8505u 6 2 + 2217618u 8 + 3905028468u 10 5 + O(u 12 ),C 4 = 49 · 2 1/2 3 3/4 17915904 , K 4 = 7 1440 √ 6π . (1.30)
We note that if we write the recursion (1.27) as follows:
C 2g = µ (5g − 6) (5g − 4) C 2g−2 + ν m+m ′ =g m,m ′ ≤g−1 C 2m C 2m ′ ,(1.31)
and if we construct the following generating function (cf. [3])
y(t) = ∞ g=0 C 2g t 1−5g 2 , (1.32)
then y(t) satisfies the Painlevé I differential equation
y ′′ (t) = y 2 (t) 8µ − C 2 0 8µ t. (1.33)
We can make the change of variables t = −cτ and u = λy to bring it to the standard form u ′′ (τ ) = 6u 2 (τ ) + τ, (1.34) see [1]. Explicitly, c = 2 −3/5 , λ = 2 3/10 3 5/4 . (1.35) The proof of Theorem 1.1 relies on the fact that the equilibrium measure for this problem is supported by a single interval [a, b] on the real axis, provided 0 ≤ u < u c . This will be shown in Section 2. As a consequence, we will be able to apply the technique developed in [15] to the proof of Theorem 1.1.

The precise structure of the coefficients F (2g) (u) of the asymptotic expansion of the free energy will be analyzed using the following steps:

• First we apply the Deift-Zhou nonlinear steepest descent method to the associated Riemann-Hilbert problem, in order to obtain the large N asymptotic expansion of the recurrence coefficients γ 2 n and β n of the corresponding orthogonal polynomials P n (z), when the index n is of the order of N . The coefficients in this asymptotic expansion will be found by using the string equations, which are nonlinear algebraic relations for γ 2 n and β n . Simultaneously, this proves the existence of the orthogonal polynomials P n (z) when the index n is of the order of N and N is large enough.

• Then we make a change of variable to reduce the cubic polynomial
V (M ) = M 2 2 − uM 3 toṼ (M ) = tM − M 3 3
, and we derive simple formulae for the partition function and the recurrence coefficients under this change of variable. The change of variable allows us to use the Toda equation that connects the second derivative of the free energyF N with respect to the parameter t to the recurrence coefficient γ 2 N . • By integrating the large N asymptotic expansion for γ 2 N term by term, we obtain detailed information about the large N asymptotic expansion of the free energy F N (u), and in particular the form of the different F (2g) (u) terms. Note that in this derivation we only need the recurrence coefficients γ 2 N and β N for large values of N , whose existence and asymptotic behavior are proved via the Riemann-Hilbert analysis before.

We note that an alternative method to derive formulae for F (2g) was proposed in [2], using the so called loop equations (see [16] for a rigorous derivation of the loop equations). In [2], explicit expressions for F (2) and F (4) are given, in terms of elementary functions that depend on the endpoints of the support of the equilibrium measure associated with the corresponding potential. In [8,19], a general heuristic formula for computing F (g) is presented for arbitrary potentials and multicut cases.

We would like also to bring attention to the very recent paper [18] of Ercolani and Pierce, which appeared after the present paper had been posted on arXiv, and which cited the present paper. In [18] a different approach, based on the so called difference string equations, is developed for the calculation of the terms of the topological expansion in the random matrix model with a general potential V (M ).

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: in Sections 2 and 3 we analyze the equilibrium measure and the corresponding Riemann-Hilbert problem for orthogonal polynomials with respect to the cubic-type weight.

In Section 4 we apply the string equations to the large N expansion of the recurrence coefficients γ 2 n and β n . This is used in Section 5 to obtain the large N expansion of the free energy F N (u), and this leads to the proof of Theorems 1.2 and Theorem 1.3 in Section 6. In Section 7 we prove Theorem 1.5, expanding the recurrence coefficients around the critical point u = u c and selecting the terms that give the dominant behavior in the free energy. Finally, Section 8 is devoted to the interpretation of the topological expansion in terms of connected graphs embedded in closed Riemann surfaces.

2. Equilibrium measure and the Riemann-Hilbert analysis 2.1. Construction. Let us denote by ̺(s) the density of the equilibrium measure for this problem, that we assume supported on a certain curve J ⊂ C with endpoints z = a and z = b. We consider J oriented from a to b, and we take the +-side on the left of J and the −-side on the right of J, following the standard convention.

The resolvent
ω(z) = J ̺(s)ds z − s (2.1)
is analytic off J, and it satisfies the Euler-Lagrange equation on J, 2) and the asymptotics at infinity,
ω + (z) + ω − (z) = V ′ (z), z ∈ J,(2.ω(z) = 1 z + O(z −2 ), z → ∞. (2.3)
To solve (2.2), we write
ω(z) = 1 2 V ′ (z) − 1 2 R(z) h(z),(2.4)
where h(z) is an analytic function and
R(z) = (z − a)(z − b),(2.5)
since we are assuming that we are in the one cut case. We take the principal sheet for R(z), with a cut on J. Due to the Plemelj formula, we have
ω − (z) − ω + (z) = 2πi̺(z) = R(z)h(z) ⇒ ̺(z) = 1 2πi R(z)h(z).
We easily deduce from (2.4) that h(z) is a polynomial of degree 1. Moreover, if we write
a = x − y, b = x + y (2.6)
and h(z) = A(z − z 0 ), then identifying the asymptotics at infinity on both sides of (2.4), we find
A = −3u, z 0 = 1 3u − x, 2x 2 + y 2 = 2x 3u , y 2 4 (1 − 6ux) = 1. (2.7)
Thus,
ω(z) = z − 3uz 2 2 − 1 2 (z − a)(z − b) (1 − 3uz − 3ux) (2.8)
and therefore
̺(z) = 1 2πi (z − a)(z − b) (1 − 3uz − 3ux). (2.9)
It follows that ̺(z) 2 has a double zero at
z 0 = 1 3u − x
and two simple roots located at z 1,2 = a, b. Next we will prove the following facts:

• For 0 ≤ u < u c , where u c is given by (1.15), the equilibrium measure is supported on an interval J = [a, b] of the real axis. The endpoints of this interval are analytic functions of the parameter u. • For 0 ≤ u < u c , we can extend the interval J to an unbounded contourΓ 0 = γ 1 ∪ J ∪ γ 2 in the upper half-plane,
C + = {z ∈ C : Im z ≥ 0},
in such a way that
φ 1 (z) > 0 z ∈ γ 1 , φ 2 (z) > 0 z ∈ γ 2 ,(2.10)
where
φ 1 (z) = 1 2 z a R(s)h(s)ds, φ 2 (z) = 1 2 z b R(s)h(s)ds.
(2.11)

Additionally, as |z| → ∞ on γ 1 and γ 2 , it is possible to estimate the growth of Re φ 1 (z) and Re φ 2 (z):
Re φ i (z) = − uz 3 3 + O(z 2 ), i = 1, 2. (2.12)
This last result is relevant in the steepest descent method applied to the Riemann-Hilbert problem, in order to show that the jump matrices outside of J tend to the identity when N → ∞.

2.2. Support of the equilibrium measure. Combining the last two equations in (2.7), we obtain the following cubic equation for the variable x as a function of the parameter u:
18u 2 x 3 − 9ux 2 + x − 6u = 0. (2.13)
If u > 0 is small, then this equation has the three solutions,
x 1 = 6u + O(u 2 ), x 2 = 1 6u + O(1), x 3 = 1 3u + O(1). (2.14)
In what follows we will be interested in the first root, x = x 1 , which is the solution that remains bounded when u is small. More terms in the expansion of x are Proof. Since by (2.14) the root x = x 1 (u) is isolated for small u, x 1 (u) is analytic at u = 0. The discriminant of cubic equation (2.13) is ∆ = 9u 2 (1 − 34992u 4 ), and it vanishes at the critical value u = u c . Hence it does not vanish for 0 < |u| < u c , and the root x 1 (u) remains isolated. This proves that x 1 (u) is analytic in the disk |u| < u c , and hence the Taylor series for x 1 (u) is convergent in this disk.
x = x 1 (u) = 6u + 324u 3 + 31104u 5 + O(u 7
It follows from the last equation of (2.7) that a similar result is valid for the variable y = y(u) > 0. Namely, y(u) is obviously analytic at u = 0. Suppose that 1 − 6ux 1 (u) = 0, then from equation (2.13) we obtain that u = 0, which contradicts 1 − 6ux 1 (u) = 0. Therefore,
1 − 6ux 1 (u) = 0, |u| < u c ,(2.17)
hence y(u) is analytic in the disk |u| < u c . This shows that for real 0 ≤ u < u c , both x = x 1 (u) and y(u) > 0 are real, so the support of the equilibrium measure is the interval [a, b] on the real axis. Moreover, the endpoints z = a and z = b are analytic functions of the parameter u.

In order to prove that we are in the one-cut regular case, we also need to show that the double root z 0 lies outside [a, b]:
Proposition 2.2. For 0 ≤ u < u c , we have that z 0 > b, so that the double root is outside the interval [a, b].
Proof. By the second equation in (2.7),
z 0 = 1 3u − x → +∞, as u → 0 + , so z 0 > b for small u > 0. Suppose that for some 0 < u < u c we have z 0 = b. Then 1 3u − x = x + y, hence 1 3u − 2x 2 = y 2 = 4 1 − 6ux , and (1 − 6ux) 3 = 36u 2 . Denote v = ux.
Then the latter equation and (2.13) give two cubic equations on v:

By applying the Euclidean algorithm to these two cubic equations, we obtain that u 2 (1−34992u 4 ) = 0, which is not true for 0 < u < u c . Therefore, z 0 > b for 0 < u < u c .

When u = u c , the support of the equilibrium measure will be the interval (2.18) and the double root of the function ̺(z) 2 is located at
[a, b] = [3 3/4 − 3 5/4 , 3 3/4 + 3 1/4 ],z c = 3 3/4 + 3 1/4 ,(2.19)
which coincides with the right endpoint of the support of the equilibrium measure.

We prove now that there exists an extension of the interval J to a curve Γ in C with right properties for the Riemann-Hilbert analysis. Proposition 2.3. There exist two curves γ 1 and γ 2 in C such that conditions (2.10) hold true.
Proof. If b < z < z 0 then (z − a)(z − b) > 0 and z − z 0 < 0 again, so Re φ 2 (z) > 0 and we can take the segment (b, z 0 ) as part of γ 2 . However, we cannot take the whole interval (b, ∞) as γ 2 , since Re φ 2 (z) < 0 if z > z 0 . Nevertheless, if we define the quadratic differential −Q(z)dz 2 , where Q(z) = 1 4 R(z)h 2 (z), (2.20)

Re φ 2 (z) = − uz 3 3 + O(z 2 ) > 0. (2.22)
This also shows that γ 2 goes to infinity with angle π/3. We can take

and hence Re φ 1 (z) > 0 for z < a, after integrating. Note that on (−∞, a) we need to take the square root with negative sign. On (−∞, a), with a similar computation as before, we have 24) and the result follows.

2.3. The Riemann-Hilbert analysis. We will consider monic orthogonal polynomials (OPs) P n (z) = z n + . . . with respect to the weight function
w(z) = e −N V (z) , (2.25) so that Γ P n (z)z k w(z)dz = 0, k = 0, 1, . . . , n − 1. (2.26)
The existence of the OPs is not obvious, since the contour Γ is complex, but the Riemann-Hilbert (RH) analysis provides us, among other properties, with the existence and uniqueness of P n (z) for large enough values of n.

The RH analysis also gives us various properties of the OPs. In particular, we will see that the OPs satisfy the three-term recurrence relation, (2.27) and that the recurrence coefficients β n , γ 2 n satisfy string and deformation equations.
zP n (z) = P n+1 (z) + β n P n (z) + γ 2 n P n−1 (z),
It is known from the work of Fokas, Its and Kitaev [20], that the family of orthogonal polynomials can be characterized as the solution of the following 2 × 2 Riemann-Hilbert problem (RHP):
Find a 2 × 2 matrix-valued Y n : C \ (Γ 0 ∪ Γ 1 ) → C 2×2 such that • Y n (z) is analytic for z ∈ C \ (Γ 0 ∪ Γ 1 ) and the limits lim s→z±0 Y n (s) = Y n± (z)
exist as s approaches z from the ±-side of Γ 0 ∪ Γ 1 . As usual, we assume that the +-side is on the left of an oriented contour.
• For z ∈ Γ 0 ∪ Γ 1 , Y n+ (z) = Y n− (z) 1 α(z)e −N V (z) 0 1 , (2.28) where α(z) = αχ Γ 0 (z) + (1 − α)χ Γ 1 (z),(2.29)
and χ A (z) denotes the characteristic function of the set A.
• As z → ∞, Y n (z) = I + O 1 z z n 0 0 z −n .
(2.30)

We will call n the degree of the RHP. This RHP has a unique solution if and only if the monic polynomial P n (z), orthogonal with respect to the weight function w(z)e −N V (z) , uniquely exists (see the next section). If additionally P n−1 (z) uniquely exists, then the solution of the Riemann-Hilbert problem is given by:
Y n (z) = P n (z) (CP n w)(z) − 2πi h n−1 P n−1 (z) − 2πi h n−1 (CP n−1 w)(z) , (2.31) where (Cf )(z) = 1 2πi Γ f (s) s − z ds (2.32)
is the Cauchy transform on Γ, and the coefficient h n−1 is defined as
h n−1 = Γ P 2 n−1 (s)w(s)ds. (2.33)
The nonlinear steepest descent method, due to Deift and Zhou (see [11] and also [12]), consists of a series of explicit and invertible transformations of this original Riemann-Hilbert problem, with the objective of arriving at a transformed problem for a 2 × 2 matrix R(z), where the matrix jumps tend to the identity uniformly in C. These steps are briefly as follows:

• Y n → T n , normalization at ∞, using the equilibrium measure on J.

• T n → S n , opening of lenses around J to convert the highly oscillatory jump on J into a combination of exponentially close to identity and constant matrix jumps. • S n → R n , construction of global and local parametrices, which are (respectively) approximations near the interval J and close to the endpoints of it. In this case, the local approximation near the endpoints z = a and z = b are given in terms of Airy functions. We refer the reader to the works [12], [10], [15] for the details. In this case, the Riemann-Hilbert analysis gives the following result:

Theorem 2.1. For any δ > 0, there exist N 0 (δ) > 0 and ε(δ) > 0 such that for any u ∈ [0, u c − δ] and any N ≥ N 0 (δ), a solution Y n (z) to the RHP (2.28)-(2.30) exists for n in the interval
I N = n : 1 − ε(δ) ≤ n N < 1 + ε(δ) . (2.34)
One of the key results also given by the Riemann-Hilbert analysis is that the recurrence coefficients γ 2 n and β n admit an asymptotic expansion in inverse powers of N for large N . We will return to these expansions later, in Section 4, but first we need to discuss various properties of the orthogonal polynomials, which follow from the RHP.


Orthogonal polynomials P n (z)

The orthogonality conditions (2.26) are equivalent to a linear system of equations for the coefficients of the orthogonal polynomial P n (z) = z n + a n−1 z n−1 + . . . + a 1 z + a 0 .

(3.1)

Namely, if
c j = Γ z j w(z)dz, (3.2) then n−1 j=0 c j+k a j = −c n+k , k = 0, 1, . . . , n − 1. (3.3)
Therefore, the orthogonal polynomial P n (z) exists and it is unique if and only if linear system (3.3) is nondegenerate, so that

An important consequence of string equations (4.3) and (4.5) is that higher order terms g 2k = g 2k (s, u) and b 2k = b 2k (s, u), k ≥ 1, can be expressed in terms of g 0 (s, u), b 0 (s, u), and their derivatives with respect to s.
